Description: A hollow terracotta head of Isis, broken from a figure. The hair is parted in the centre, with a diadem above, surmounted by a horned crown, with disc and feathers. Summary detail of crown at the back. A suspension-hole is pierced from side-to-side, through the feathers. The break at the lower edge was smoothed down in modern times. Two-piece mould. Orange-buff marl clay, with a pink surface. Traces of a white dressing on the front.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased in 1814: P.-E. Towneley. From the collections of Charles Townley. Previously belonging to the traveller Richard Pococke, and acquired by him, probably at Coptos, in 1737. Probably Ptolemaic, third or second century bc. Comparandum. Near: Warmenbol 1998: 270, pl. 2:2. Bibliog. Pococke 1743: 213, pl. lxiv:D.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3005)
